newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil court overrules Band B disqualifications.
newsitem.headline: Brazil court overrules Band B disqualifications.

text.p: A Brazilian high court Tuesday allowed three groups to continue bidding for cellular Band B concessions, overruling their disqualification by the Ministry of Communications, a spokeswoman said.
The spokeswoman for the Superior Justice Tribunal (STJ) said its president Judge Americon Luz had ruled in favor of the Algar, Lightel and Hutchison-Cowan consortia.
"They can now bid tomorrow (Wednesday) for the Sao Paulo concession," she said.
The Algar and Lightel groups consist of private telecommunications operator Lightel, construction company Queiroz Galvao and two South Korean telephone companies.
The Hutchison-Cowan consortium is made up of Hong Kong telecommunications group Hutchison Whampoa Ltd and Brazilian construction group Cowan Construtora.

The STJ on Monday overturned the disqualification of another group, the Tess consortium of Swedish operator Telia, Brazil's Airline Cellular and Primave, part of Brazil's CR Almeida construction company.
The STJ spokeswoman said the reason for the rulings had been the same in all cases, namely that the ministry's grounds for disqualifying the bidders had been "too excessive in its formalities."

In all, five groups were disqualified and the STJ spokeswoman said judges were also considering an appeal from the Telet consortium. That group is made up of Bell Canada, a unit of BCE Inc, Telesystem Telecom Ltd, Brazil's state-run Banco do Brasil, Brazilian pension funds, the Opportunity Bank and Citicorp.

The government was due Wednesday to open bids for what many regard as potentially the most lucrative of the 10 concession areas, the Sao Paulo metropolitan area. Bids for the Bahia and Sergipe state areas were also due to be opened.
